snippet: With some commutes into the city taking three hours, New Yorkers clung to news that some subway and rail service would be restored on Thursday.
abstract: Transportation systems slow to crawl in most of New York metropolitan area day after Hurricane Sandy, amid promises that some subway and commuter rail services will be restored by next day's morning commute; area residents are beleaguered with commutes into city taking hours, half-mile lines at suburban gas stations and city buses stuffed beyond capacity; Gov Andrew Cuomo declares transportation emergency and waives fares on commuter trains, subways and buses for remainder of week.

byline.original: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER and JOHN LELAND

lead_paragraph: With some commutes into the city taking three hours, New Yorkers clung to news that some subway and rail service would be restored on Thursday.

headline.seo: New Yorkers Cling to Hope of a Better Commute
headline.main: Long Gas Lines, Clogged Roads and Slim Hope for a Better Day
headline.print_headline: Long Gas Lines, Clogged Roads, And Slim Hope for a Better Day
headline.sub: MTA Waives Fares; Restrictions on Bridges in New York
